name: Diwali - The Festival of Lights
description: Diwali (Deepavali), meaning 'row of lights,' stands as the most celebrated festival in the Hindu calendar, a five-day celebration of light's triumph over darkness, knowledge over ignorance, and good over evil. The festival commemorates Lord Rama's return to Ayodhya after fourteen years of exile and his victory over the demon king Ravana. Celebrated across India and the Hindu diaspora with unparalleled fervor, Diwali transforms homes into radiant sanctuaries through the lighting of countless diyas (oil lamps), spectacular fireworks, elaborate rangoli designs, the exchange of sweets and gifts, and devoted worship of Goddess Lakshmi, the divine bestower of wealth and prosperity.

origins.mythologicalBasis: The primary narrative associates Diwali with the return of Lord Rama, his wife Sita, and brother Lakshmana to Ayodhya after their fourteen-year exile and Rama's defeat of the demon king Ravana in Lanka. The citizens of Ayodhya lit countless oil lamps to welcome their beloved prince home, creating a festival of illumination.
alternativeOrigins: In South India, Diwali celebrates Krishna's victory over the demon Narakasura
For Jains, it marks Mahavira's attainment of nirvana
For Sikhs, it commemorates Guru Hargobind's release from imprisonment
Some traditions connect it to Lakshmi's emergence from the churning of the cosmic ocean (Samudra Manthan)
origins.historicalContext: References to Diwali appear in ancient Sanskrit texts including the Padma Purana and Skanda Purana. The festival has been celebrated for over 2,500 years, evolving to incorporate regional traditions and multiple religious narratives.

timing.calendarPlacement: Diwali falls on the new moon night (Amavasya) in the Hindu month of Kartik (October-November), determined by the lunar calendar

fiveDayStructure.significance: Worship of Dhanvantari (god of medicine) and purchase of gold and utensils
Krishna's victory over Narakasura; ritual oil baths before dawn
Main day; lighting of diyas and worship of Lakshmi and Ganesha
Krishna lifting Govardhan Hill; mountains of food offerings

participants: Jain, Sikh, and some Buddhist communities

steps.name: Preparation and Cleaning
steps.description: Homes are thoroughly cleaned, renovated, and whitewashed to welcome Lakshmi, who is believed to visit only clean homes

steps.name: Rangoli Creation
steps.description: Colorful floor designs using colored powder, flower petals, or rice are created at entrances to welcome deities and guests

steps.name: Diya Lighting
steps.description: Oil lamps (diyas) are lit throughout the home, on windowsills, rooftops, and courtyards to dispel darkness

steps.name: Lakshmi-Ganesha Puja
steps.description: Formal worship of Lakshmi (prosperity) and Ganesha (remover of obstacles) with flowers, incense, sweets, and mantras

steps.name: Fireworks and Celebration
steps.description: Communities celebrate with fireworks, sparklers, and gatherings

steps.name: Feasting and Exchange
steps.description: Elaborate meals, exchange of sweets (mithai), gifts, and new clothes

tools.name: Diyas
tools.description: Traditional clay oil lamps filled with ghee or mustard oil

tools.name: Rangoli materials
tools.description: Colored powders, flower petals, rice, or sand for floor designs

tools.name: Puja thali
tools.description: Ceremonial plate with flowers, incense, camphor, vermillion, and rice

tools.name: Murtis
tools.description: Images or idols of Lakshmi, Ganesha, and sometimes Saraswati

prohibitions: Gambling (though ritual gambling is traditional in some regions as Lakshmi is associated with luck)
Negative speech or actions during puja
Leaving the home dark or unlit

mythologicalRole.cosmicSignificance: Diwali represents the eternal triumph of light (sat) over darkness (tamas), knowledge over ignorance, and dharma over adharma. The lighting of lamps symbolizes the inner light of consciousness dispelling the darkness of illusion.
mythologicalRole.divinePatronage: Lakshmi, goddess of wealth, fortune, and prosperity, is the central deity of Diwali worship. Her presence brings material and spiritual abundance to households that properly welcome her.
mythologicalRole.ritualRenewal: Diwali marks a new year in many Hindu communities, symbolizing fresh beginnings, settled accounts, and renewed relationships

legacy.culturalImpact: Diwali has become one of the world's most recognized festivals, celebrated by over a billion people across India and the global diaspora. It represents Hindu culture's message of hope and renewal.
legacy.economicSignificance: The festival drives significant economic activity in India, with massive consumption of gold, sweets, textiles, and consumer goods. It is comparable to Christmas in commercial importance.
legacy.globalRecognition: Diwali is now recognized and celebrated in countries worldwide, with official holidays in several nations and celebrations at major landmarks globally.
legacy.environmentalAwareness: Modern celebrations increasingly emphasize eco-friendly practices, including reduced fireworks and sustainable materials
